qas.question: Are all sources of the crucification literary?

answers.text: almost all ancient sources relating to crucifixion are literary

qas.question: What evidence was found that Crucifixion did happen?
Who was the crucified man discovered in an archaeological find?
What institution holds a heel bone with a spike inserted?
When did the Romans first take the city of Hagkol?
What year was the Israel Museum established?

plausible_answers.text: the body of a crucified man

qas.question: What discovery was made northeast of the city of Hagkol?
What was the average age of Roman soldiers?
What did the Romans keep as a deterrent to others who would revolt?

context: Although <a0_0>almost all ancient sources relating to crucifixion are literary<a0_0/>, <a1_0>the <b6_0>1968<b6_0/> archeological discovery<a1_0/> just northeast of Jerusalem of <b7_0>the body of a crucified man<b7_0/> dated to the 1st century provided good confirmatory evidence that crucifixions occurred during the Roman period roughly according to the manner in which the crucifixion of Jesus is described in the gospels. The crucified man was identified as Yehohanan <a2_0>ben Hagkol<a2_0/> and probably died <a3_0>about 70 AD<a3_0/>, around the time of the Jewish revolt against Rome. The analyses at the Hadassah Medical School estimated that he died in his late <b8_0>20s<b8_0/>. Another relevant archaeological find, which also dates to the <b5_0>1st century AD<b5_0/>, is an unidentified <b9_0>heel bone with a spike<b9_0/> discovered in a Jerusalem gravesite, now held by the Israel Antiquities Authority and displayed in the <a4_0>Israel Museum<a4_0/>.
